src.data_visualization.avg_velocity module

src.data_visualization.avg_velocity.all_velocity(df_list)[source]

Collects all velocities from a list of DataFrames and returns them as a single list

Parameters:

df_listlist

A list of DataFrames, each containing ‘X’, ‘Y’, and ‘time’ columns

Returns:

list

A list of all velocities calculated from the DataFrames

src.data_visualization.avg_velocity.avg_velocity(df)[source]

Calculates the average velocity between consecutive points in a DataFrame

Parameters:

dfpd.DataFrame

A DataFrame containing ‘X’, ‘Y’, and ‘time’ columns

Returns:

list

A list of velocities between consecutive points in the DataFrame

src.data_visualization.avg_velocity.calc_velocity(point1, point2)[source]

Calculates the velocity between two points based on their X, Y coordinates and time

Parameters:

point1pd.Series

The first point containing ‘X’, ‘Y’, and ‘time’ values

point2pd.Series

The second point containing ‘X’, ‘Y’, and ‘time’ values

Returns:

float

The calculated velocity between the two points

src.data_visualization.avg_velocity.plot_histogram(data, bins=10)[source]

Plots a histogram of the given data, representing the distribution of velocities

Parameters:

datalist

A list of velocity values to be plotted

binsint, optional

The number of bins to use in the histogram (default is 10)

src.data_visualization.split_table_dev module

src.data_visualization.split_table_dev.save_tables(tables, folder_path)[source]

Saves a list of dataframes as csv files

Parameters:

tables: list

A list of DataFrames to be saved

folder_path: str

The directory path where the CSV files will be saved

src.data_visualization.split_table_dev.split_table(df, save_to_folder=False, folder_path=None)[source]

Splits valid data into tables

Parameters:

df: pd.dataframe

The input dataframe to be split

save_to_folder: bool, optional

If True, the resulting tables will be saved as CSV files in the specified folder (default is False)

folder_path: str, optional

The directory path where the CSV files will be saved, if save_to_folder is True

Returns:

List

A list of DataFrames, each representing a subset of the original DataFrame without infinite values

src.data_visualization.visualizer module

class src.data_visualization.visualizer.DaphniaAnimation(df, start_index=0)[source]

Bases: object

Animates the movement of a Daphnia using clean data from an NPZ file

Functions:

__init__:

Initializes the DaphniaAnimation class with the given NPZ file and start index

load_data:

Loads data from NPZ file into dataframes and removes missing data if needed

plot_detail:

Sets the title and labels for the plot

init_animation:

Initializes the animation by setting the line data to empty

animate:

Updates the animation frame by frame

create_animation:

Creates and displays the animation of the Daphnia’s movements

animate(i)[source]

Updates the animation frame by frame

Parameters:

i: int

The current frame index

Returns:

tuple

A tuple containing the updated line object

create_animation()[source]

Creates and displays the animation of the Daphnia’s movements

The function sets up the plot, removes missing data if needed, adds plot details, and then runs the animation

init_animation()[source]

Initializes the animation by setting the line data to empty

Returns:

A tuple containing the line object to be animated

plot_detail(title, xlabel, ylabel)[source]

Sets the title and labels for the plot

Parameters:

title: str

Title of the plot

xlabel: str

The label for the X-axis

ylabel: str

The label for the Y-axis
